arr = [1, 2, 3]

# Common Operations
arr.index(1)      # Find index
arr.append(1)     # Add to end
arr.insert(0,10)  # Add 10 from left (at index 0 which is start)
arr.remove(3)     # Remove value
arr.pop()         # Remove & return last element
arr.sort()        # In-place sort (TimSort: O(n log n))
arr.sort(reverse=True)  # In-place reverse (High to low)
arr.reverse()     # In-place reverse
arr.copy()        # Return shallow copy

# List Slicing
arr[start:stop:step]  # Generic slice syntax
arr[-1]    # Last item
arr[::-1]  # Reverse list
arr[1:]    # Everything after index 1
arr[:3]    # First three elements

# Sublists (aka slicing), å·¦é—­å³å¼€
arr[1:2]   # [2]
# Similar to for-loop ranges, last index is non-inclusive
# But no out of bounds error
arr[0:10]  # [1, 2, 3]

# Custom sort (e.g., by length of string)
arr = ["bob", "alice", "jane", "doe"]
arr.sort(key=lambda x: len(x))
print(arr)  # ['bob', 'doe', 'jane', 'alice']

# 2-D lists
arr = [[0] * 4 for i in range(4)]
print(arr)
print(arr[0][0], arr[3][3])

# This won't work
# arr = [[0] * 4] * 4

# Tuples are immutable lists

# Essential Operations

# Useful Patterns

# Common Operations
s.add(4)             # Add element
s.remove(4)          # Remove (raises error if missing)
s.discard(4)         # Remove (no error if missing)

# Set Operations
a.union(b)           # Elements in a OR b
a.intersection(b)    # Elements in a AND b
a.difference(b)      # Elements in a but NOT in b

a.issubset(b)        # True if all elements of a are in b
a.issuperset(b)      # True if all elements of b are in a

# Valid numeric strings can be converted

# Queues (double ended queue)
from collections import deque

# Perfect for BFS - O(1) operations on both ends
d = deque()
d.append(1)          # Add right
d.appendleft(2)      # Add left
d.pop()              # Remove right
d.popleft()          # Remove left
d.extend([1,2,3])    # Extend right
d.extendleft([1,2,3])# Extend left
d.rotate(n)          # Rotate n steps right (negative for left)

import heapq

# MinHeap Operations - All O(log n) except heapify
nums = [3,1,4,1,5]
heapq.heapify(nums)          # Convert to heap in-place: O(n)
heapq.heappush(nums, 2)      # Add element: O(log n)
smallest = heapq.heappop(nums)  # Remove smallest: O(log n)

# MaxHeap Trick: Multiply by -1
nums = [-x for x in nums]    # Convert to maxheap: O(n)
heapq.heapify(nums)          # O(n)
largest = -heapq.heappop(nums)  # Get largest: O(log n)

# Advanced Operations
k_largest = heapq.nlargest(k, nums)    # O(n * log k)
k_smallest = heapq.nsmallest(k, nums)  # O(n * log k)

# Custom Priority Queue
heap = []
heapq.heappush(heap, (priority, item))  # Sort by priority

# Under the hood are arrays
minHeap = []
heapq.heappush(minHeap, 3)
heapq.heappush(minHeap, 2)
heapq.heappush(minHeap, 4)

# Min is always at index 0
print(minHeap[0])  # 2

while len(minHeap):
    print(heapq.heappop(minHeap))
# 2
# 3
# 4

# No max heaps by default, work around is
# to use min heap and multiply by -1 when push & pop.
maxHeap = []
heapq.heappush(maxHeap, -3)
heapq.heappush(maxHeap, -2)
heapq.heappush(maxHeap, -4)

# Max is always at index 0
print(-1 * maxHeap[0])  # 4

while len(maxHeap):
    print(-1 * heapq.heappop(maxHeap))
# 4
# 3
# 2

# Build heap from initial values
arr = [2, 1, 8, 4, 5]
heapq.heapify(arr)
while arr:
    print(heapq.heappop(arr))
# 1
# 2
# 4
# 5
# 8

# Iteration Helpers

def two_pointers(arr):
    n = len(arr)
    if n == 0:
        return 0  # æˆ–å…¶ä»–é»˜è®¤å€¼

    # Step 1: åˆå§‹åŒ–æŒ‡é’ˆ
    left = 0                    # å·¦æŒ‡é’ˆ / æ…¢æŒ‡é’ˆ
    # right = 0 æˆ– n - 1ï¼Œæ ¹æ®æ–¹å‘é€‰æ‹©

        # Step 3: æ‰©å±•æˆ–ç§»åŠ¨å³æŒ‡é’ˆåï¼Œå¤„ç†å½“å‰çª—å£/çŠ¶æ€
        # ... æ›´æ–°çŠ¶æ€

        while left <= right and need_to_move_left(arr, left, right):
            # ... æ›´æ–°æˆ–è®°å½•ç»“æœ

"""
ğŸ“–æè¿°ï¼šç»™ä½ ä¸¤ä¸ªæŒ‰ éé€’å‡é¡ºåº æ’åˆ—çš„æ•´æ•°æ•°ç»„ `nums1` å’Œ `nums2`ï¼Œå¦æœ‰ä¸¤ä¸ªæ•´æ•° `m` å’Œ `n`ï¼Œåˆ†åˆ«è¡¨ç¤º `nums1` å’Œ `nums2` ä¸­çš„å…ƒç´ æ•°ç›®ã€‚è¯·ä½  åˆå¹¶ `nums2` åˆ° `nums1` ä¸­ï¼Œä½¿åˆå¹¶åçš„æ•°ç»„åŒæ ·æŒ‰ éé€’å‡é¡ºåº æ’åˆ—ã€‚
ğŸ§ªæ ·ä¾‹ï¼šè¾“å…¥ï¼šnums1 = [1,2,3,0,0,0], m = 3, nums2 = [2,5,6], n = 3ï¼›è¾“å‡ºï¼š[1,2,2,3,5,6]
ğŸ’¡é‡ç‚¹ï¼šä»åå¾€å‰æ“ä½œå¯ä»¥ç›´æ¥è¦†ç›–
"""

def merge(nums1: List[int], m: int, nums2: List[int], n: int) -> None:
    """
    Do not return anything, modify nums1 in-place instead.
    """
    # é€†å‘åŒæŒ‡é’ˆï¼Œä»åå¾€å‰æ“ä½œå¯ä»¥ç›´æ¥è¦†ç›–
    p1, p2 = m - 1, n - 1  # åŒå‘ï¼Œä½†æ˜¯ä»åå¾€å‰
    tail = m + n - 1  # éœ€è¦ç»´æŠ¤çš„çŠ¶æ€ï¼šå½“å‰éœ€è¦å¤„ç†çš„ç´¢å¼•
    while True:
        if p1 < 0 or p2 < 0:
            break
        if nums1[p1] <= nums2[p2]:
            nums1[tail] = nums2[p2]
            p2 -= 1
            tail -= 1
        else:
            nums1[tail] = nums1[p1]
            p1 -= 1
            tail -= 1
    # ç”±äºæ¯”è¾ƒï¼Œæ€»ä¼šæœ‰ä¸€ä¸ªæ•°ç»„å…ˆç»“æŸï¼Œå¯¹äºåç»“æŸçš„ä¸€ä¸ªæ•°ç»„ï¼šè¿™é‡Œè‚¯å®šæ˜¯p2
    if p2 >= 0:
        nums1[: p2 + 1] = nums2[: p2 + 1]

def merge(nums1: List[int], nums2: List[int]) -> List[int]:
    """ åˆå¹¶åŒæŒ‡é’ˆï¼ŒéåŸåœ°æ“ä½œã€‚
    ğŸ§ªæ ·ä¾‹ï¼šè¾“å…¥ï¼šnums1 = [1,2,3], nums2 = [2,5,6]ï¼›è¾“å‡ºï¼š[1,2,2,3,5,6]
    """
    m, n = len(num1), len(nums2)
    new_list = []
    i, j = 0, 0
    # åˆå¹¶çš„è¿‡ç¨‹åªèƒ½æ“ä½œ i, j çš„ç§»åŠ¨ï¼Œä¸è¦å»ç”¨ list1.pop(0) ä¹‹ç±»çš„æ“ä½œ
    # å› ä¸º pop(0) æ˜¯ O(n) çš„æ—¶é—´å¤æ‚åº¦ï¼Œè€Œä¸”ä¼šæ”¹å˜åºå·
    while True:
        if i >= m or j >= n:
            break
        if nums[i] < nums[j]:
            new_list.append(nums[i])
            i += 1
        else:
            new_list.append(nums[j])
            j += 1
    # åˆå¹¶å‰©ä¸‹çš„æ•°åˆ° new_list é‡Œ
    while i < m:
        new_list.append(nums[i])
        i += 1
    while j < n:
        new_list.append(nums[j])
        j += 1
    return new_list

def mergeTwoLists(list1: ListNode, list2: ListNode) -> ListNode:
    dummy = ListNode()  # è™šæ‹Ÿå¤´ç»“ç‚¹ï¼Œå®ƒçš„å”¯ä¸€ä½œç”¨å°±æ˜¯æä¾›ä¸€ä¸ªèµ·å§‹ç‚¹ï¼Œè®© p å¯ä»¥ä¸æ–­å‘åè¿æ¥èŠ‚ç‚¹
    p = dummy  # p æŒ‡å‘è™šæ‹Ÿé“¾è¡¨çš„æœ«å°¾
    p1 = l1
    p2 = l2

        # å°†å€¼è¾ƒå°çš„çš„èŠ‚ç‚¹æ¥åˆ° p æŒ‡é’ˆ
        if p1.val > p2.val:

            p2 = p2.next
        else:
            p.next = p1
            p1 = p1.next

        p = p.next

    if p1 is not None:
        p.next = p1

    if p2 is not None:
        p.next = p2

    return dummy.next  # æ³¨æ„ï¼šä¸æ˜¯è¿”å›æŒ‡é’ˆ pï¼Œè€Œæ˜¯è¿”å›é“¾è¡¨çš„å¤´éƒ¨ï¼Œä¹Ÿå°±æ˜¯ dummy.next

"""
ğŸ“–æè¿°ï¼šç»™ä½ ä¸€ä¸ªå­—ç¬¦ä¸² `s`ï¼Œæ‰¾åˆ° `s` ä¸­æœ€é•¿çš„ å›æ–‡ å­ä¸²ã€‚
ğŸ§ªæ ·ä¾‹ï¼šè¾“å…¥s = "babad"ï¼›è¾“å‡º"bab"æˆ–"aba"ã€‚è¾“å…¥ï¼šs = "cbbd"ï¼›è¾“å‡ºï¼š"bb"ã€‚
ğŸ’¡é‡ç‚¹ï¼š
- éœ€è¦åŒæ—¶è€ƒè™‘å¥‡æ•°å’Œå¶æ•°é•¿çš„å›æ–‡ä¸²
- ä¸­å¿ƒæ‰©æ•£
- è¿™é¢˜è¿˜å¯ä»¥ç”¨åŠ¨æ€è§„åˆ’è§£: 
    - çŠ¶æ€å®šä¹‰ï¼šdp[i][j]è¡¨ç¤ºs[i:j+1]æ˜¯å¦ä¸ºå›æ–‡
    - åˆå§‹åŒ–ï¼šdp = [[False for _ in range(size)] for _ in range(size)]
    - è½¬ç§»æ–¹ç¨‹ï¼šdp[i][j] = dp[i-1][j-1] and s[i] == s[j]
"""
def longestPalindrome(s: str) -> str:
    n = len(s)
    if n <= 1:
        return s
    max_s, max_len = "", 0
    for i in range(n):
        if n - 1 - i < (max_len - 1) / 2:
            break  # æå‰ç»ˆæ­¢
        # å¤„ç†å¥‡æ•°é•¿åº¦çš„å›æ–‡å­ä¸²ï¼Œä»¥iä¸ºä¸­å¿ƒå‘ä¸¤è¾¹ç§»åŠ¨
        left, right = i, i
        while True:
            if left < 0 or right > n - 1:
                break
            if s[left] == s[right]:
                left -= 1
                right += 1
            else:
                break  # æ³¨æ„æ‰€æœ‰breakçš„æƒ…å†µ
        cur_len = right - left - 1
        if cur_len > max_len:
            max_s = s[left + 1 : right]
            max_len = cur_len
        # å¤„ç†å¶æ•°é•¿åº¦çš„å›æ–‡å­ä¸²
        left, right = i, i + 1
        while True:
            if left < 0 or right > n - 1:
                break
            if s[left] == s[right]:
                left -= 1
                right += 1
            else:
                break
        cur_len = right - left - 1
        if cur_len > max_len:
            max_s = s[left + 1 : right]
            max_len = cur_len
    return max_s

def lengthOfLongestSubstring(s: str) -> int:
    N = len(s)
    ans = 0
    for l in range(N):
        substr = {s[l]}
        for r in range(l + 1, N):
            if s[r] not in substr:
                substr.add(s[r])
            else:
                break
        ans = max(ans, len(substr))
    return ans

# æ­£ç¡®ç”¨æ³• 1
# råªå¢ä¸å‡ï¼šO(N), 23ms
def lengthOfLongestSubstring(s: str) -> int:
    N = len(s)
    right, ans = 0, 0
    for left in range(N):
        substr = s[left:right]
        while True and right < N:
            if s[right] in substr:
                break
            else:
                right += 1
                substr = s[left:right]
        ans = max(ans, len(substr))
    return ans

# æ­£ç¡®ç”¨æ³• 2
# windowç»´æŠ¤æ¯ä¸ªå­—ç¬¦å‡ºç°çš„æ¬¡æ•°, åˆ é™¤ s[left] ç›´è‡³ win[s[right]] <= 1, O(N), 76ms
def lengthOfLongestSubstring(s: str) -> int:
    win, ans = dict(), 0
    left, right = 0, 0
    while right < len(s):
        win[s[right]] = win.get(s[right], 0) + 1
        # æ»‘åŠ¨å·¦æŒ‡é’ˆç›´åˆ°win[s[right]]<=1
        while win[s[right]] > 1:
            win[s[left]] -= 1
            left += 1
        ans = max(ans, right - left + 1)
        right += 1
    return ans

# é”™è¯¯è§£æ³•
# æš´åŠ›æšä¸¾ï¼Œæ¯æ¬¡å¾ªç¯éƒ½é‡æ–°è®¡ç®—Counterï¼Œæ—¶é—´å¤æ‚åº¦ O(N^2)
def checkInclusion(s1: str, s2: str) -> bool:
    from collections import Counter

    N, M = len(s1), len(s2)
    ref = Counter(s1)
    # çª—é•¿å§‹ç»ˆä¸ºN
    for i in range(M):
        substr = s2[i: i + N]
        win = Counter(substr)
        if win == ref:
            return True
    return False

# æ­£ç¡®è§£æ³•
# ä¸éœ€è¦æ¯æ¬¡éƒ½é‡æ–°è®¡ç®—ï¼Œåªéœ€è¦æ›´æ–° left å’Œ right çš„è®¡æ•°ï¼Œæ—¶é—´å¤æ‚åº¦ O(N)
def checkInclusion(s1: str, s2: str) -> bool:
    N, M = len(s1), len(s2)
    if N > M:
        return False

    ref = {}
    for c in s1:
        ref[c] = ref.get(c, 0) + 1

    window = {}
    for i in range(N):
        window[s2[i]] = window.get(s2[i], 0) + 1

    right = N
    while right < M:
        # print(window)
        if window == ref:
            return True
        new = s2[right]
        old = s2[right - N]
        # ç»´æŠ¤æ»‘åŠ¨çª—
        window[new] = window.get(new, 0) + 1
        window[old] = window.get(old, 0) - 1
        if window[old] == 0:
            del window[old]
        right += 1

    if window == ref:
        return True
    return False

def hash_search(arr, query):
    # å“ˆå¸ŒæŸ¥æ‰¾ï¼Œç”¨äºæ— åºæ•°ç»„
    seen = {}
    for i, val in enumerate(arr):
        complement = query - val
        if complement in seen:
            return [seen[complement], i]  # å¦‚ä¸¤æ•°ä¹‹å’Œ
        seen[val] = i
    return -1

def binary_search(array, query):
    """ Two points. [low, high] will be splitted:
        (1) [low, mid - 1]
        (2) [mid]
        (3) [mid + 1, high]
    """
    low, high = 0, len(array) - 1  # é—­åŒºé—´ [left, right]
    while low <= high:
        mid = low + (high - low) // 2  # é˜²æº¢å‡º
        val = array[mid]
        # array[low:mid], array[mid], array[mid+1:high+1]
        if val == query:
            return mid
        if val < query:
            low = mid + 1
        else:
            high = mid - 1
    return None

def binary_search_recur(array, low, high, query):
    """ Recurrence. [low, high] will be splitted:
        (1) [low, mid - 1]
        (2) [mid]
        (3) [mid + 1, high]
    """
    if low > high:
        return -1
    mid = low + (high - low) // 2   # This mid will not break integer range
    if query < array[mid]:
        return binary_search_recur(array, low, mid - 1, query)  # Go search in the left subarray
    if query > array[mid]:
        return binary_search_recur(array, mid + 1, high, query)  # Go search in the right subarray
    return mid  # `array[mid] = query`, stop recurrence

ğŸ§ªæ ·ä¾‹ï¼šè¾“å…¥ï¼š`nums = [2,3,4,5,6,7,0,1]`, `target = 0`ï¼›è¾“å‡ºï¼š`target`çš„ä¸‹æ ‡ä¸º`6`ã€‚
ğŸ’¡é‡ç‚¹ï¼š
1. æ•°ç»„ä¸æ˜¯æœ‰åºçš„ï¼Œä½†æ˜¯æ˜¯å±€éƒ¨æœ‰åºçš„ã€‚æœ‰åºçš„é‚£ç«¯ä¸€å®šæ˜¯æœ€å·¦è¾¹å°äºæœ€å³è¾¹ï¼Œæ— åºçš„é‚£ç«¯ä¸€å®šæ˜¯æœ€å·¦è¾¹å¤§äºæœ€å³è¾¹ã€‚
2. ç›®æ ‡æ˜¯å¦åœ¨æœ‰åºéƒ¨åˆ†æ¯”è¾ƒå¥½åˆ¤æ–­`nums[left_] <= target and target < nums[right_]`ï¼Œå¦‚æœä¸æ»¡è¶³åˆ™è½åœ¨å¦ä¸€è¾¹ã€‚
https://leetcode.cn/problems/search-in-rotated-sorted-array/solutions/2636954/javapython3cer-fen-cha-zhao-you-xu-de-ba-5g7e
"""
def search(nums: List[int], target: int) -> int:
    low, high = 0, len(nums) - 1
    while low <= high:
        mid = low + (high - low) // 2
        val = nums[mid]
        # print(mid, nums[low:mid], nums[mid], nums[mid+1:high+1])
        if val == target:
            return mid
        if low < mid and nums[low] <= nums[mid - 1]:
            # å·¦è¾¹æœ‰åºï¼Œå…ˆåˆ¤æ–­æ˜¯å¦åœ¨å·¦è¾¹
            if nums[low] <= target and target <= nums[mid - 1]:
                high = mid - 1
            else:
                low = mid + 1
        elif mid < high:
            # å³è¾¹æœ‰åºï¼Œå…ˆåˆ¤æ–­æ˜¯å¦åœ¨å³è¾¹
            if nums[mid + 1] <= target and target <= nums[high]:
                low = mid + 1
            else:
                high = mid - 1
        else:
            return -1
    return -1

"""
ğŸ“–æè¿°ï¼šç»™å®šä¸€ä¸ªæ’åºå¥½çš„æ•°ç»„ `arr`ï¼Œä¸¤ä¸ªæ•´æ•° `k` å’Œ `x`ï¼Œä»æ•°ç»„ä¸­æ‰¾åˆ°æœ€é è¿‘ `x` çš„ `k` ä¸ªæ•°ã€‚è¿”å›çš„ç»“æœå¿…é¡»è¦æ˜¯æŒ‰å‡åºæ’å¥½çš„ã€‚
ğŸ§ªæ ·ä¾‹ï¼šè¾“å…¥ï¼š`arr = [1,2,3,4,5]`, `k = 4`, `x = 3`ï¼›è¾“å‡ºï¼š`[1,2,3,4]`ã€‚

1. åå‘æ€ç»´ï¼Œåˆ é™¤æœ€è¾¹ç¼˜çš„`n - k`ä¸ªï¼Œæ¯æ¬¡åˆ¤æ–­åˆ æœ€å·¦è¾¹è¿˜æ˜¯åˆ æœ€å³è¾¹ã€‚
2. è¿”å›ç»“æœè¦æ’å¥½åºï¼Œå¯ä»¥ç”¨åŒæŒ‡é’ˆå¯»æ‰¾æœ€ä¼˜å­åŒºé—´ã€‚
"""

def findClosestElements(arr: List[int], k: int, x: int) -> List[int]:
    # æ’é™¤æ³•ï¼ˆåŒæŒ‡é’ˆï¼‰
    N = len(arr)
    remove_nums = N - k
    left, right = 0, N - 1
    while remove_nums:
        # æ³¨æ„ï¼šè¿™é‡Œç­‰äºå·çš„å«ä¹‰ï¼Œé¢˜ç›®ä¸­è¯´ï¼Œå·®å€¼ç›¸ç­‰çš„æ—¶å€™å–å°çš„
        # å› æ­¤ç›¸ç­‰çš„æ—¶å€™ï¼Œå°½é‡ç¼©å°å³è¾¹ç•Œ
        if x - arr[left] <= arr[right] - x:
            right -= 1
        else:
            left += 1
        remove_nums -= 1
    return arr[left:left + k]

"""
ğŸ“–æè¿°ï¼š
    ç»™å®šæ•´æ•°æ•°ç»„ nums å’Œæ•´æ•° kï¼Œè¯·è¿”å›æ•°ç»„ä¸­ç¬¬ k ä¸ªæœ€å¤§çš„å…ƒç´ ã€‚
    è¯·æ³¨æ„ï¼Œä½ éœ€è¦æ‰¾çš„æ˜¯æ•°ç»„æ’åºåçš„ç¬¬ k ä¸ªæœ€å¤§çš„å…ƒç´ ï¼Œè€Œä¸æ˜¯ç¬¬ k ä¸ªä¸åŒçš„å…ƒç´ ã€‚
    ä½ å¿…é¡»è®¾è®¡å¹¶å®ç°æ—¶é—´å¤æ‚åº¦ä¸º O(n) çš„ç®—æ³•è§£å†³æ­¤é—®é¢˜ã€‚
ğŸ§ªæ ·ä¾‹ï¼š
    è¾“å…¥: [3,2,1,5,6,4], k = 2
    è¾“å‡º: 5

    è¾“å…¥: [3,2,3,1,2,4,5,5,6], k = 4
    è¾“å‡º: 4
ğŸ’¡é‡ç‚¹ï¼š
"""
class Solution:
    def partition(self, nums: List[int], left: int, right: int) -> int:
        """
        åœ¨å­æ•°ç»„ [left, right] ä¸­éšæœºé€‰æ‹©ä¸€ä¸ªåŸºå‡†å…ƒç´  pivot
        æ ¹æ® pivot é‡æ–°æ’åˆ—å­æ•°ç»„ [left, right]
        é‡æ–°æ’åˆ—åï¼Œ<= pivot çš„å…ƒç´ éƒ½åœ¨ pivot çš„å·¦ä¾§ï¼Œ>= pivot çš„å…ƒç´ éƒ½åœ¨ pivot çš„å³ä¾§
        è¿”å› pivot åœ¨é‡æ–°æ’åˆ—åçš„ nums ä¸­çš„ä¸‹æ ‡
        ç‰¹åˆ«åœ°ï¼Œå¦‚æœå­æ•°ç»„çš„æ‰€æœ‰å…ƒç´ éƒ½ç­‰äº pivotï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬ä¼šè¿”å›å­æ•°ç»„çš„ä¸­å¿ƒä¸‹æ ‡ï¼Œé¿å…é€€åŒ–
        """

        # 1. åœ¨å­æ•°ç»„ [left, right] ä¸­éšæœºé€‰æ‹©ä¸€ä¸ªåŸºå‡†å…ƒç´  pivot
        i = random.randint(left, right)
        pivot = nums[i]
        # æŠŠ pivot ä¸å­æ•°ç»„ç¬¬ä¸€ä¸ªå…ƒç´ äº¤æ¢ï¼Œé¿å… pivot å¹²æ‰°åç»­åˆ’åˆ†ï¼Œä»è€Œç®€åŒ–å®ç°é€»è¾‘
        nums[i], nums[left] = nums[left], nums[i]

        # 2. ç›¸å‘åŒæŒ‡é’ˆéå†å­æ•°ç»„ [left + 1, right]
        # å¾ªç¯ä¸å˜é‡ï¼šåœ¨å¾ªç¯è¿‡ç¨‹ä¸­ï¼Œå­æ•°ç»„çš„æ•°æ®åˆ†å¸ƒå§‹ç»ˆå¦‚ä¸‹å›¾
        # [ pivot | <=pivot | å°šæœªéå† | >=pivot ]
        #   ^                 ^     ^         ^
        #   left              i     j         right

        i, j = left + 1, right
        while True:
            while i <= j and nums[i] < pivot:
                i += 1
            # æ­¤æ—¶ nums[i] >= pivot

            while i <= j and nums[j] > pivot:
                j -= 1
            # æ­¤æ—¶ nums[j] <= pivot

            if i >= j:
                break

            # ç»´æŒå¾ªç¯ä¸å˜é‡
            nums[i], nums[j] = nums[j], nums[i]
            i += 1
            j -= 1

        # å¾ªç¯ç»“æŸå
        # [ pivot | <=pivot | >=pivot ]
        #   ^             ^   ^     ^
        #   left          j   i     right

        # 3. æŠŠ pivot ä¸ nums[j] äº¤æ¢ï¼Œå®Œæˆåˆ’åˆ†ï¼ˆpartitionï¼‰
        # ä¸ºä»€ä¹ˆä¸ j äº¤æ¢ï¼Ÿ
        # å¦‚æœä¸ i äº¤æ¢ï¼Œå¯èƒ½ä¼šå‡ºç° i = right + 1 çš„æƒ…å†µï¼Œå·²ç»ä¸‹æ ‡è¶Šç•Œäº†ï¼Œæ— æ³•äº¤æ¢
        # å¦ä¸€ä¸ªåŸå› æ˜¯å¦‚æœ nums[i] > pivotï¼Œäº¤æ¢ä¼šå¯¼è‡´ä¸€ä¸ªå¤§äº pivot çš„æ•°å‡ºç°åœ¨å­æ•°ç»„æœ€å·¦è¾¹ï¼Œä¸æ˜¯æœ‰æ•ˆåˆ’åˆ†
        # ä¸ j äº¤æ¢ï¼Œå³ä½¿ j = leftï¼Œäº¤æ¢ä¹Ÿä¸ä¼šå‡ºé”™
        nums[left], nums[j] = nums[j], nums[left]

        # äº¤æ¢å
        # [ <=pivot | pivot | >=pivot ]
        #               ^
        #               j

        # è¿”å› pivot çš„ä¸‹æ ‡
        return j

    def findKthLargest(self, nums: list[int], k: int) -> int:
        n = len(nums)
        target_index = n - k  # ç¬¬ k å¤§å…ƒç´ åœ¨å‡åºæ•°ç»„ä¸­çš„ä¸‹æ ‡æ˜¯ n - k
        left, right = 0, n - 1  # é—­åŒºé—´
        while True:
            i = self.partition(nums, left, right)
            if i == target_index:
                # æ‰¾åˆ°ç¬¬ k å¤§å…ƒç´ 
                return nums[i]
            if i > target_index:
                # ç¬¬ k å¤§å…ƒç´ åœ¨ [left, i - 1] ä¸­
                right = i - 1
            else:
                # ç¬¬ k å¤§å…ƒç´ åœ¨ [i + 1, right] ä¸­
                left = i + 1

entry.title: Configure Waline with TiDB
entry.content:
Why Waline + TiDB?

Waline is a lightweight, open-source, privacy-focused, and self-hosted comment system with backend UI and rich features, and TiDB Cloud offers a scalable, MySQL-compatible database with a generous 5GB free tier â€“ making them a powerful pair for efficient and reliable comment system.

How to Set Up Waline with TiDB Cloud?

Follow these steps to deploy and configure Waline using TiDB Cloud as the database backend.

  1. Create a cluster in TiDB Database (any name is okay)

  2. Connect with the above cluster in your local editor (e.g., VS Code)

    To manage your database and initialize comment tables:

    1. Get Connection Details: In the TiDB Cloud console (Overview of the cluster), click the Connect button (top-right corner). Youâ€™ll see the connection parameters HOST, PORT, USERNAME, PASSWORD (generate and copy it), DATABASE and CA.

    2. Set Up VS Code: See details in TiDB Developer Guide.

    3. Initialize the Waline Database Schema: Copy waline.tidb and execute the entire script in VS Code. The script will create a database named waline with wl_Comment, wl_Counter and wl_Users in it.

  3. Configure Environment Variables as listed in Waline Guidebook

When first connecting via VS Code, the default Database is test. After running waline.tidb, the actual database used by Waline is waline. So in Environment Variables, set DATABASE = waline.

entry.title: Customize Your Jekyll Chirpy Theme
entry.content:
Jekyll Chirpy Theme is a highly customizable theme with a large number of users and a very complete ecology. You can reproduce or adjust the configuration according to the official wiki to realize your own magic modification.

This blog introduces some basic tutorials to customize your own Chirpy theme, suitable for those friends who are not satisfied with the Chirpy configuration and want more blogging functions. Welcome to issue or join us to help others build blogs.

  • Exchange Homepage and About

  • Replace Disqus with Valine for Discussion

  • Use Waline for Discussion
entry.summary: Jekyll Chirpy Theme is a highly customizable theme with a large number of users and a very complete ecology. You can reproduce or adjust the configuration according to the official wiki to realize your own magic modification.
